FILE: cm663678v11.0.txt
DYAD: JORDAN - YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC(N.)
RIVALRY: RIV1259
DISPUTE(S): MID1108 

PS-NOTES:

PS-LAST-CHANGED: 20180920
PS-LAST-CHECKED: 20181006

Territorial-Maritime-Boundary Issues Variables

MID1108

TERRMID: MID1108 3 -- not territory
TERRMID-CER: MID1108 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID1108 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID1108 1 -- certain
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID1108 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID1108 1 -- certain
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID1108 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID1108 1 -- certain
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID1108 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID1108 1 -- certain
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID1108 from Gibler 2018, the Royalists were armed and received arms support from the UK, making them a militarized rebel group. See COUPMID-NOTES. 

CIVWARLINK: MID1108 3 -- not civil war link
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID1108 1 -- certain
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID1108 1 -- coup MID
COUPMID-CER: MID1108 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: MID1108 from Gibler 2018, the leader of Yemen died in 1962, leaving his son Mohammad al-Badr in charge of the country. A military leader staged a coup, and al-Badr fled the country. The USSR, China, and Egypt recognized the new government. The exiled Royalists established a government-in-exile and were supported by Saudi Arabia. Jordan supported the Royalists. Saudi troops clashed with Yemeni troops in Yemen, and Egypt attacked the Saudis. Jordanian troops also clashed with Yemeni troops. Coded coup MID because this was connected to a coup in Yemen, within this dyad. 

COUPLINK: MID1108 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID1108 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

RIVNOTES: 

NARRATIVE-CM:

SOURCES-CR:

SOURCES: Gibler, D.M. 2018. Militarized Interstate Dispute Narratives, 1816-2010. Langham, MD: Rowman and Littlefield.
